the baltic states are likely to be hit hard by russia 's ban on almost all food coming from the west , writes mats persson from open europe .

when lithuanian president dalia grybauskaite ( who by the way would have made an excellent european commission president ) was asked earlier this year if she did n't fear putin , she referred to when lithuania , as the first soviet republic , declared independence in 1990 , leading moscow to impose eight-month long sanctions against vilnius .
grybauskaite said , no hot water .
no energy .
we were sitting with our gloves and coats in our offices we survived .
we 're not afraid and we 're used to this neighbour . ''

he argues that there is a moral case of sorts '' go compensate the disproportional burden shouldered by these three states as a result of the sanctions , but notes the potential complications of such a move .
if you give compensation to one , you have to give to others .
if the situation escalates this could suddenly become an unexpectedly large cost ( think france and mistral ) .
as we 've warned before , that 's the thing about sanctions , for better or worse , they 're unpredictable .
and what form would the compensation take ?
would it come from the eu budget or via individual member states ?
and , would eu countries be able to agree ?
there 's been plenty of activity in the oil markets today , after the us started bombing iraq .
the pentagon announced that us warplanes struck artillery that was being against kurdish forces defending the regional stronghold of irbil .
brent crude rose more than $ 1 during the day but has since pared gains , to trade below $ 106 a barrel .
it is now trading 42 cents up on the day at $ 105.86 a barrel .
the rouble is set to end the week close to an all-time low following the announcement that moscow would ban most food imports from the west in retaliation for sanctions over ukraine .

igor akinshin of alfa bank said : the markets are preparing for the worst based on what 's going on in east ukraine , where the fighting continues , no one wants to agree with anyone and russia is building up troops on the border .
the rouble fell 1.7 % against the dollar , nearly hitting its all-time low of 36.73 , last seen in march after russia annexed ukraine 's crimea peninsula .
back to the co-op and another lukewarm response to the restructuring it announced this morning ( see below ) .
the institute of directors says : in broad terms , the proposals announced today by the co-op are a step in the right direction .
nonetheless , the overall governance structure at the co-op remains somewhat confusing .

indeed , the co-op group needs to adapt its governance model to the realities of the modern global economy , just as private sector boards have needed to become more professional over the last decade .
we remain concerned that of the nine members of the board , three will still be elected by other members .
without an entirely independently appointed board , there remain concerns about how much independent oversight the board will be able to exercise .

this was an opportunity for a decisive change of direction for the co-op and whilst significant progress has been made , we would like them to have gone further in addressing their governance problems .

documents.title: rbs disbands unit accused of wrecking small businesses
text: royal bank of scotland is disbanding its controversial global restructuring group ( grg ) , which was previously accused of deliberately forcing customers into default to make a profit .
derek sach , the head of the division , will leave the bank , as will aubrey adams , who headed up the property function within grg .
max colchester at the wsj reports : laura barlow has been appointed to head up rbs 's restructuring activities .
her team will work alongside the group 's existing businesses to help clients who are struggling with repayments .
some of the assets that are currently being restructured are being moved to the state-owned bank 's bad bank , '' these people say .

rbs was accused last november in a report by a former government adviser , lawrence tomlinson , of putting some distressed commercial clients out of business in order to scoop up assets for its own west register property business .

but clifford chance , the law firm commissioned by rbs to undertake an inquiry into the tomlinson allegations , said there was no evidence '' of fraudulent activity , although it criticised other aspects of the bank 's practices .

sach was defending the group just two months ago , insisting that it was not a profit centre , was not aggressive to its customers and had not threatened to remove overdrafts from small business customers .
he told mps on the treasury select committee : generally [ i ] do believe we do good overall .
derek sach is leaving rbs , as it disbands the global restructuring group he headed up .

market update at lunchtime .
the ftse is down by 0.5 % , having regained some ground after hitting a near four-month low of 6552 points earlier in the day .
hantec markets analyst richard perry said : at every corner , it seems that something else comes out of the woodwork that gives people another reason to sell .

some more reaction to the uk economic data .

chris williamson at markit says : the trade figures are some of the worst seen in recent history , and likely worsen further in july after pmi survey data showed manufacturing expanded at the slowest rate for a year in july , caused primarily by a deterioration in export growth .
exporters are being hit on two fronts .
first , an appreciating exchange rate , which has risen 10 % over the past year , is making uk-produced goods more expensive abroad .
second , already weak demand in many overseas markets is being hit further by growing uncertainty about the ukraine crisis , especially in northern europe .
escalating geopolitical events in gaza and iraq add to the sense that global risk aversion is creeping higher , which will inevitably mean slower economic growth .
rob wood at berenberg bank says the conflicting data highlights the lopsided nature of the recovery .

escalating tensions in ukraine seem to be weighing on the internationally exposed manufacturing sector , but construction output , the strong services pmi and rapidly rising house prices suggest the domestic recovery still has plenty of legs .
there 's some tub-thumping from the british chambers of commerce .

david kern says : [ the disappointing trade ] figures confirm that the pace of the uk 's rebalancing towards net exports is far too slow , and if this continues we risk missing out on the prime minister 's target of increasing exports to £ 1tn by 2020 .
if we in britain are serious about rebalancing our economy , we must invest even more in supporting and promoting international trade .
on its part , the mpc must resist calls for early interest rate rises and reassure businesses that when rates start rising , increases will be modest and gradual to avoid any unwelcome surprises .
lord myners , the city veteran charged with reforming the co-op , has responded to the group 's reforms announced today .
he said : the proposals do not go as far as i recommended in my review of governance but they represent significant progress in the right direction .
the acid test will be whether they are able to attract outstanding candidates to join the board without compromising on necessary standards .
there needs to be rigorous application of a high test for membership of the board given the demanding business challenges facing the group .

the commitment to setting the bar at the right level wold be greater if those lay directors who have sat on the board over the last five disastrous years made clear that they accepted that they fell well short of the new standard and said that they would not be standing for election to the board .

back to italy , where parliament approved a package of support measures for the ailing economy late last night , including a cut in energy costs for small companies and measures to encourage lending to businesses .

but reuters reports that many fear the reforms do not go far enough : the package , dubbed the competitiveness decree '' when it was presented by prime minister matteo renzi 's government in june , got a lukewarm reception from business leaders who said it lacked a clear strategy and failed to address the real needs of industry .

prominent industrialist alberto bombassei , chairman of brake-maker brembo , said the competitiveness decree contained too many minor measures and was of no help to business which would benefit far more from a reduction in corporate tax rates .
it seems a clear sign that the government has lost its direction at the moment , '' he said in an interview in la stampa daily on friday .
italian prime minister matteo renzi is under pressure to deliver reforms , after the country slid into a triple-dip recession .

joshi herrmann writes : the [ financial conduct authority ] says it ca n't confirm or deny whether it is investigating burrows but a spokesman said that , hypothetically , a crime such as not paying for train fares could speak to the character '' of an individual , pricking its interest .

when deciding whether someone was fit and proper to operate in finance , the fca said : one of the matters is whether the person has been the subject of any adverse finding or any settlement in civil proceedings , particularly in connection with investment or other financial business , misconduct , [ or ] fraud . ''
mario draghi may have chosen to holiday there but he was pretty damning about italy in the ecb press conference yesterday , saying it can only blame itself for slipping into a triple-dip recession .
more on bloomberg .

reporters stefan riecher and alessandro speciale point out that italy ranked 65th out of 189 countries globally in the world bank ease-of-doing-business survey , right behind st. lucia , belarus and fiji .
the glaxosmithkline trial has begun in china .

our reporter in shanghai , jonathan kaiman reports : a british man and his american wife have appeared in a shanghai court in the first formal hearing after they were accused of illegally obtaining private information about chinese citizens .
peter humphrey , 58 - a coporate sleuth hired by glaxosmithkline - and his 61-year-old wife , yu yingzeng , have been detained since last july on sus of using illegal means to get the data .
gsk 's china office , which is currently the target of a separate corruption probe , was one of their last clients .
the year-long case has sent chills through the country 's foreign business community .
here 's capital economics on the uk trade data .
june 's trade data provide further evidence that the economic recovery is struggling to rebalance towards the external sector .
there are plenty of headwinds which mean that exporters may continue to struggle in the near term .
for one , the full effects of sterling 's appreciation over the past year have probably not been felt yet .
and second , the euro-zone 's economic recovery remains extremely fragile .
accordingly , we doubt that the trade deficit will narrow substantially over the rest of the year .

text: uk construction data is more upbeat , with a 1.2 % increase in june , after falling by the same amount in may .
that means construction is up by 5.3 % in the year to june .

shaun richards makes a good point about trade figures constantly missing forecasts .
reuters does point out : the [ uk 's ] trade performance has been volatile in recent months due to so-called erratic goods such as aircraft , which are high in value and traded infrequently .
overall the value of goods exports fell by 1.9 % in june ; imports fell by 0.3 % .
exports to the eu were little changed .
the uk government has been trying to help british exporters , but its efforts have been hampered by weak demand in the eurozone .

documents.title: british trade deficit widens to £ 2.5bn
text: the uk 's trade gap widened unexpectedly in june , as eurozone troubles hit demand for british exports .
the ons said the trade deficit for goods grew to £ 9.4bn from £ 9.2bn in june , compared with forecasts that it would shrink to £ 8.8bn .
the trade surplus in services partially offset those figures , shrinking the overall trade deficit to £ 2.5bn .
the us intervention in iraq is just the latest in a string of events to hit the markets .

alternative economics reports that investors took $ 7.1bn out of junk bond funds in the past week a record amount , according to lipper '' .
wolf richter writes : after having been inflated to dizzying proportions , the junk-bond bubble has been pricked .
and the hot air is hissing out of it .
overnight , embattled malaysia airlines was taken into state hands after two high-profile disasters that killed hundreds of people .
agencies in kuala lumpur report : the business outlook for the malaysian flagship carrier deteriorated after one of its aircraft , flight mh370 , disappeared on 8 march .
the airline 's problems deepened on 17 july when another jet , flight mh17 , was shot down over ukraine , killing all 298 people on board .

the disastrous run sped up efforts for the government to restructure the airline , sources said - even before two almost unfathomable crashes the carrier 's financial performance was among the worst in the industry .
the disasters sparked a slump in bookings , which hurt already struggling operations .
malaysia 's state investment fund will pay 1.4 billion ringgit ( £ 260m ) to buy out the company , a 12.5 % premium to the closing share price on thursday .

the independent has a good story on hsbc , which has been accused of shamelessly profiling '' its customers by ethnicity and closing bank accounts belonging to syrian refugees and students in the uk .

maria tadeo reports : documents and email correspondence obtained by the independent show that hsbc , which styles itself as the world 's local bank '' , sent letters to syrian clients living in the uk telling them their accounts would be closed and giving them two months to find a new bank .
it cited increased requirements for compliance with international obligations concerning payments to and from sanctioned countries '' .
the letters claimed that the decision to terminate their accounts was based on the bank 's own assessment of risk '' and did not reflect the manner in which they conducted their business .
the world 's oldest bank , monte dei paschi di siena , posted a huge loss in the second quarter , almost three times bigger than analyst forecasts .
italy 's third biggest bank - which received €4.1bn in state aid last year - said net losses for the three months to june stood at €179m .
that compares with forecasts of a €57.5m loss .

reuters reports : bad loans are the major problem for italian banks ahead of a pan-european review of lenders ' assets and they are a major troublespot for monte dei paschi in particular because it has the highest proportion of soured loans among italian lenders .
official figures out this week showed italy slid into recession again , which will make it even harder for banks to keep a lid on bad debts .

in the uk , the troubled co-operative group has unveiled proposals to change the way it is run , including crucial concessions on its board structure .

while former city minister lord myners had recommended removing all the democratically elected members of the co-op from the board , the mutual is now offering those members three seats on the board .

there were very strong trade figures out of china overnight , pushing the trade surplus for july to an all-time high of $ 47.3bn .
that is a 50 % increase on june , and 170 % higher than last year .
exports surged 14.5 % from last year , to hit $ 213bn , as markets around the world recover , driving demand for chinese goods .
imports dropped 1.6 % to $ 166bn , helped by declines in commodity prices .
stock markets around the world fell and oil surged , as investors reacted to news that the us will carry out airstrikes on iraq .

obama said in a late night statement : when we face a situation like we do on that mountain , with innocent people facing the prospect of violence on a horrific scale and we have a mandate to help - in this case a request from the iraqi government - and when we have unique capabilities to act to avoid a massacre , i believe the united states can not turn a blind eye , '' the president said in a late-night statement from the white house .
japan 's nikkei closed almost 3 % down , while australian shares were 1.3 % lower .
european markets are expected to follow suit .
brent crude jumped 0.9 % to $ 106.39 a barrel , as the prime oil-producing region plunged further into chaos .
investors fled to safe haven assets , driving prices of us treasuries higher and yields down .
the yield on 10-year treasuries stood at 2.4 % .
